title: What will be the lowest closing spot price for West Texas Intermediate crude oil, according to the US Energy Information Agency, between 14 September 2015 and 30 December 2015?
preds: I mean let's not be silly this is a very easy prediction to make with three trading days left in the year and oil trading at 37. The options market on the USO etf is giving less than a 1% chance that oil will go down more than 5% by 12/31/2015. There is also a less than 1% chance that the oil etf will go up by more than 5%. Since options have baked in time value and volatility premia, I think the actual likelihood of those events is basically zero. This range also happens to be in the perfect place to make a 100% prediction--literally in the middle of 34 and 40 dollars.
WTI's volatility range within the past three weeks strongly suggests a price safely within the (34-40) boundary for the next two days.

The price of WTI increased further today on forecasts of colder weather this winter causing an increase in demand for oil and gas. Also President Obama vetoed the Keystone Pipeline project again which will limit U.S. oil refining in Texas, and prevent increases in oil supplies in the U.S.

Question apparently closed midnight 29/30th. Not what I was expecting, although I guess it was indicated in the "Closing Date" field. I don't think I was alone in misinterpreting this, for otherwise everyone would have gone 100% after market close Tuesday but before midnight Tuesday/Wednesday question close. Nevertheless, it seems like the full trading day of the 30th should have been included. Another instance of two "competing truths." I must admit that this was, perhaps due to its feature of daily feedback, my "go to" question on GJI, and I'm a bit lost now that it has concluded. I suspect my involvement will diminish from this point forward. It was fun, and I learned a lot.

>$40 excluded because the price has fallen below this at the date of prediction submission. a reasonably speculative market [ see https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/wp/2014/wp14218.pdf] one would anticipate a reasonably high likelihood of the market bottoming out with a 'capitulation' which flushes out the shorters.  Alternatively the price won't show sustained increases until there is evidence that the over-supply is coming to an end [e.g. OPEC agree at their next meeting, turmoil in the straits of hormuz etc, US production declines significantly, invasion of Ukraine]. BASED ON CURRENT PRICE - $34 WOULD NEED A CIRCA 10% SHIFT DOWN. I would anticipate continued downward movement unless signs emerge that the over-supply is coming to an end.  The most likely of these would be an OPEC policy shift, or signs that higher interest rates will curtail high-debt USA production.  Middle east turmoil which significantly affects oil prices is fairly uncommon [less than once every 7 years over recent decades].  but i'm always wary of underestimating the likelihood of 'unknown unknowns'. Unless such a supply-shock comes within 2016 Q1, the downward momentum, capitulation of shorters etc is likely to mean we see a breach of $34 at close of day within that period. During Q2 AND Q3 LIK

We are totally in the dark today as to the true WTI spot price. The price that many people think is the "WTI spot" price is actually the "WTI February Future Contract." As discussed previously, there is a price differential between these two, which is greatest around the first trading day of the new future month contract (which is today). So, while we may suspect that these two prices are correlated, we do not know the real WTI spot price; and will need to wait until tomorrow to find out. Last month, the differential was -$2.48 on the first trading day of the new future month contract. Just a word of caution is all. "West Texas Intermediate for February delivery gained as much as 35 cents to U$36.16 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange by 5.17 pm. Sydney time. The January contract expired Monday after rising 1 cent to US$34.74."
http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/energy-commodities/oil-halts-decline-near-6-year-low-before-us-inventory-data According to the above, the price differential between January expiration and February initiation was -$1.42 at the close yesterday. So, at least for myself, I am going to assume that any February WTI Futures price I see today is approximately $1.50 higher than the true WTI spot. Whatever the differential is (which we will learn from the EIA report tomorrow), it will diminish over time. Last month the differential was reduced to zero in around seven days.

As a note to everybody forecasting a decline in WTI oil prices as a result of opening US oil to export - I believe the better way to look at this is that prices should rise if oil exports are allowed. The world's clearing price of oil is effectively Brent ($38.50ish) and WTI represents the US oil clearing price. If you open WTI prices to a global market that currently clears at a higher price, WTI can only converge upward to Brent. WTI crude also tends to be of higher quality than Brent crude.

At an annual volatility (1 Standard Dev) of 45%-50%, the lower bound of 1 standard deviation price in 3 weeks is about 10%-12% below the current price...which is around $34...just below the cutoff. So if I say that there is a 15% chance that the volatility spikes up and a 85% chance that it doesn't,

Just yesterday I posted a forecast which included a discussion on how Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have begun to pay the shipping charges on behalf of their customers as an incentive to buy their oil (thus reducing the "effective price"): https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/53160  Well, it seems such incentives have worked, since today we learn that shippers are raising their tanker rates based on increased bookings (and perhaps the fact that Saudi Arabia is now picking up the tab). SA is obviously fully committed to pushing out every barrel they can, no matter what it takes to move it. (Beside increased bookings, tanker rates might also be more expensive since some % of the gross fleet is out-of-service while being used as floating storage.) The more the price of oil moves away from "list price" to incentive-based "effective pricing," the less reliable the "list price" becomes as a signal of market supply/demand imbalance. It's not like the oil markets weren't complicated enough already.
http://article.wn.com/view/2015/12/03/Oil_Tanker_Rates_Soar_From_Middle_East_as_Traders_Boost_Book/ There are also, apparently, other unidentified off-list "deals" going on to generate lower effective prices: "You're now seeing a slight divergence between the official stated price of oil on the market and what you're actually able to buy it for."

Revised projection to 92% / 8% from 90% / 10% - rationale: standard deviation in 2015 of wti spot rate has been about $6, last price was 39.27--indicating c. 15% chance of reaching a price below 34. Futures for Jan. delivery are just above 41, so it feels like market participants are not predicting further falls... but as we know the market's often wrong so I'm not placing a lot of weight on this data point. There are a couple of factors at work pushing the standard deviation derived probability estimate down. First, US oil rigs continue to drop slowly and production remains either static or decreasing. I have assumed this is the primarily supply of WTI crude and would indicate a static or increasing WTI spot price. Second, US refineries are coming off of seasonal maintenance at the end of November through mid December. Crude stockpiles appear to be beginning to fall (http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/06/us-usa-refining-kemp-idUSKCN0SU39420151106#ZCzCZ0cyHT6T5zql.97) as refineries return to average levels of production, which would increase demand for crude to turn it into refined products (gasoline, propane, etc.). Third, I'm making a broad judgement that OPEC is not able to increase production beyond the level of the additional refinery draw on existing supply of WTI crude (c. 500,000 - 900,000 bpd). There is a correlation between OPEC production and global oil prices and WTI prices due to arbitrage. The OPEC meeting in December bears watching carefully but my feeling is that impact on WTI crude SPOT prices will be minimal (but have a much larger impact on futures).

Like you, I'm practicing forecasting. Read more on my blog: https://superforecasting.squarespace.com - On November 23, the closing price is already down to $39.21, so there is, by definition, 0% chance that the lowest closing price will be "more than $40 per barrel".
- So the question now becomes: what's the probability that the price will close for $34 or less in the next 31 days, or rather, what's the probability the price of oil will fall by 13% in the next 31 days?
- since there is a deep and liquid market for WTI futures, you could try to imply the expected price from that, however, since oil can be stored, the futures price is not necessarily the expected future price of oil. Also, the expected future price also doesn't answer the question - the question is about the lowest closing price on any given day.
- given that it's only a forecast over 31 days, I did a basic model. I looked at how many times the price had decreased by 13% or more over any 31 day period over the last year or over the last two years. This happened 16% to 17% of the time. Hence my estimate of 16% for "less than $34 per barrel".

While I still believe that USD 40.00 remains an important psychological marker, at least for the close, recent price action and recent global geopolitical developments are making me adjust my forecast: I still see < USD 34.00 as unlikely. We would need to see a major price drop over the next six weeks and apart from a significant policy change by the Fed, I do not see any predictable event that would cause this. For the remaining two options, I am starting to favour the USD 34.00 to 40.00 range, which I will also reinforce to counter my previous forecast. I see a major downside risk in the anticipated Fed rate hike in Mid-December, which the recently released October minutes strongly indicating this (for a more thorough dot-plot analysis, refer to the markets blog of your choice). Should we continue to stay near the USD 40.00 range until then, a drop below the USD 40.00 marker seems likely. 
However, if the last two years have taught us anything, it is not to trust too much in the Fed’s guidance. A slight upside risk would be major military action in the Middle East, following the surge of terrorist attacks in recent weeks. However, Daesh’s contribution to the international oil market seems to be very minor, so I doubt we would see a noteworthy supply-driven price move. I certainly do not want to fully discount this risk though, as it might arise more from the signal any military action would send rather than its actual impact.

Oil is trading in a relatively fixed range right now.  The Saudis and their allies along with large Western oil producers (Exxon, BP, Royal Dutch She'll, etc.) can operate on oil below $60 a barrel as long as it stays above $40 a barrel.  This gives them an opportunity to simultaneously punish three groups he need >$60 a barrel to effectively operate: The Dakotas and Canada, Iran, and Russia.  If oil creeps to close to $60 they will increase supply.  If it closes below $40 expect to hear about a refinery fire or some other such supply constriction.  I suspect that we will see at least one close below $40 during this time period but it won't be sustained and the majority of the time it will remain above $40 a barrel.
Oil will end up settling into the range of $30-40 USD unless like World War Three breaks out.

I've come around to @redacted's (and the Economist's) view that the oversupply issues are ongoing, and storage capacity is maxing out (hence, supply will be growing faster than demand). If the trend that started since my last prediction holds, then it'll go below $34 by the end of December. I added a little more nuance to my method, which is based upon historical trends. I've done linear projections to 31/12/2015 using a number of different time frames (since '86, '05, '10, Q1 '15, Q2 '15, Q3 '15). I've also assigned weights to the different time frames, with a bias around 1/10/2015. Hence the probabilities are based upon the weighted average of the predictions (e.g. if the sum of the timeframe weights predicting below $34  is 5, and the total sum of timeframe weights is 20, then I would put 25% for <$34). From today New York Times (excerpts from a longer article) HOUSTON — Such is the state of the oil industry these days that there is sometimes nowhere to put the oil. Off the coast of Texas, a line of roughly 40 tankers has formed, waiting to unload their crude or, in some cases, for a willing buyer to come along. Similar scenes are playing out off the coasts of Singapore and China and in the Persian Gulf. There is little sign that the logjam will ease, as the price of oil continued its yearlong plunge this week, declining by nearly $10 a barrel. The renewed collapse in crude prices is helping to again drive down gasoline prices for American drivers, to a national average of $2.19 a gallon for regular gasoline on Friday, according to the AAA motor club. That is 9 cents below the price a month ago and 73 cents below the price a year ago. The slide in oil companies’ fortunes has been significant because of expanded production in Russia, Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states, as well as a slowdown in demand growth in China and the expectation by commodity traders that the Iran nuclear deal will introduce large quantities of oil to the glutted market. The surge in production has led to a global stockpile of three billion barrels of crude, roughly the equivalent of a month of world oil production. The global market has not been this saturated since 2009, when demand for fuel plummeted. “This massive cushion,” the International Energy Agency, based in Paris, noted in a report on Friday, has produced “an unprecedented buffer against geopolitical shocks or unexpected supply disruptions.” The report helped to decrease the price of West Texas Intermediate, an American benchmark in oil pricing, by more than a dollar at one point on Friday. It almost reached $40 a barrel, its lowest level since last summer and before that in 2009. Oil prices were above $100 a barrel as recently as the summer of 2014. The glut has left the tanks in Cushing, Okla., and other domestic supply depots brimming. The Energy Department noted that American crude inventories had grown last week to 487 million barrels and were nearly a third higher than a year ago. It was the seventh weekly increase in a row. Despite the glut, tankers full of African and Middle Eastern oil are still making their way to the Gulf of Mexico, in part because markets in Asia are also oversupplied. But energy experts say that despite the huge stockpiles, the oil market could easily be shaken by a crisis in the Middle East, like a major terrorist attack in Saudi Arabia or a collapse in Iraq, and prices could soar again. “The market is myopic,” said Steven Wood, a managing director at Moody’s Corporate Finance Group. “There is no spare capacity in the world. The market isn’t pricing in any risk, geopolitical risk, for oil.” Still, Moody’s projects that oil prices will rise slowly, to an average for West Texas Intermediate crude of $48 a barrel in 2016 and $55 in 2017. The global Brent benchmark, now just under $44 a barrel, will rise to $53 in 2016 and to $60 in 2017, Moody’s projects. Behind the low price projections is a sluggish world economy, experts say. The I.E.A. report on Friday suggested that world demand growth for oil would slow in 2016 to 1.2 million barrels a day after reaching a five-year high of 1.8 million barrels a day in 2015. Low commodity prices and tight financing have forced oil companies in the United States to decommission more than half of their rigs, leading to tens of thousands of layoffs in oil states like Texas, North Dakota and Oklahoma. To keep their leases, and unwilling to pay while drilling rigs already under contract stand idle, many operators are drilling wells without completing them — meaning that as soon as prices begin to revive, they can quickly complete the wells and begin production, thus forcing prices down again. Behind the low price projections is a sluggish world economy, experts say. The I.E.A. report on Friday suggested that world demand growth for oil would slow in 2016 to 1.2 million barrels a day after reaching a five-year high of 1.8 million barrels a day in 2015.

"Many businesses minimize physical inventories they own over the year-end for accounting purposes by agreeing to sell them before December 31 and buy them back in January. There is an active market for year-end sale and repurchase transactions and plenty of intermediaries in the market will arrange them, with associated need to juggle hedges and futures positions."
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/13/us-oil-prices-kemp-idUSKCN0T21AA20151113 If there is anything I'd hope to accomplish before retiring from this project is to have heightened the awareness in some of you to the significance of appreciating the difference between "that which is reported" and "that which is real." In the above example, the firms still control those inventories, so from a practical (realistic) perspective they still "own" them. That they can maneuver the legal title of the inventory to an entity that reports separately while retaining control of the inventory is a great example. You can gauge the value of this deception but seeing what transaction costs they are willing to incur to engage in it. All this is done to deceive their very own shareholders. Whenever any transaction is engaged in "for accounting purposes," you should simply translate this into "for the purposes of deceiving shareholders." [Edit: And, oh, why these transactions are relevant to the Question: this desire to engage in moving this inventory off the books should bring some of the hoarders to market as sellers, thus resulting in downward pressure on prices. And the REALLY interesting thing about these deals, is that so long as the benefit they gain from the deception is greater than the transaction costs, they will be motivated to pursue the transaction. That is, there's a "deception benefit" that offsets a strict attention to "the best price."]

This gets a bit complicated, and we gain insight into the activity at Cushing; namely, that oil stocks at Cushing are not exclusively composed of standing WTI oil, and, more importantly, that capacity utilization at Cushing is running high. The following item is found in the link provided by @ed3 ( https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/34432 ): "Cushing, OK stock was -0.79-M bbl to 53.33-M bbk. Utilization rate +1.2% to 87.6%."
1) Unless I am missing something, the implication of this statement (Cushing stocks going down yet capacity utilization going up) is that either: a) storage capacity was reduced (which I doubt) or b) some other grades of oil (and other factors*) share or effect the Cushing storage facilities along with WTI, and the stocks or share of those non-WTI factors increased at Cushing at a rate faster than the stocks of WTI at Cushing decreased. 2) A scan of news articles suggests this 87.6% utilization is near the record rate of 91% set in 2011. Despite the market action last week, which to my (admittedly non-specialist) mind bears the indications of a manipulation, the Cushing capacity utilization crunch has not gone away. In addition, despite the hype that low prices are driving out WTI producers and closing wells, "WTI Crude Oil production [nevertheless] rose 3.15% to 4.88-M BPD" last week. Assuming storage capacity utilization increases at the rate it did last week, Cushing will be full in ten weeks, nine of which are in the window of this Question (reporting lags a week). Since Cushing has never before been in a situation where its capacity has been tested, it is an open question as to what the real, actual, true physical storage capacity is, as such actual capacities are typically found to be +/- of the estimated capacity. *Background info on Cushing stocks versus storage capacity utilization

Based upon previous 5 years, the lowest price for the 4th quarter will have been seen by the end of October (i.e. now). For 2015, this has been well above $40/barrel, hence a forecast of 80% for >$40/barrel. However, the exception in the past 5 years is the last year when oil prices fell off a cliff. My understanding of the driving factors is that there is both a glut in the supply (Frackers, Saudi Arabia doing it's best to take on Russia and Frackers) and a demand shortfall (China and emerging markets in general). Looking at the 4th quarter of 2015, on the demand side, the emerging market situation seems stable but US demand is forecast to drop slightly on the previous year. I think any big shocks down will be on the supply side. Iranian oil sanctions are being lifted, and that oil should be entering the market around the end of the year (I think it unlikely to be within the 4th quarter though). The markets should have priced that in, but there has been disagreement on the impacts. Hence, I have weighed the remaining 20% probability budget mostly (15%) towards a slight reduction($34/barrel < price < $40/barrel), with a small chance (5%) of a dramatic decrease. I'm sticking with Goldman. It's a classic expectations versus fundamentals scenario. One has to adjust to the other sooner-or-later. The chatter (expectations) are all focused on the effects of reduced production next year. We're talking about a spot market here with twelve weeks of trading before 2016. Traders, imo, have just loaded a ton of hype upon the one real bullish impetus of the declining dollar. There is a glut in the market, little excess storage capacity, and diminishing demand. Update regarding Iran: I had always assumed that Iran would not become a factor until 2016, but a question following my last forecast prompted me to do some more research: 
US and EU sanctions on Iran's oil trade will be lifted on the Implementation Day of the deal i.e. "simultaneously with the IAEA-verified implementation of agreed nuclear-related measures by Iran". 
While no specific date is fixed, it is generally agreed that the Implementation Day will be sometime in H1CY16 (within 4-6 months of the Adoption Day (19/10/2015). The question is whether progress reports on the implementation in the coming months will have a decreasing effect on price. 
Personally, I doubt that it will be significant and might even be met with profit taking by counterparties before implementation and the following price effects. In summary, this research reaffirms my priorly assigned probabilities. Sources: 
Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action - https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/2165399/full-text-of-the-iran-nuclear-deal.pdf
Timeline Summary - http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/07/14/iran-nuclear-timeline-idUKL5N0ZU38O20150714

While I'm sure that at the margin there are some people that increase usage based on lower pricing ("Sure, we can drive to that festival two states away next weekend"), I'm thinking that for the most part demand from consumer autos is relatively inelastic. Most people, I believe, take whatever money they save at the pump and spend/reinvest it elsewhere. It's not like they say, "Wow, gas is cheap today, I'll buy a few extra gallons to take home and share it with my friends, or store it (and for safety reasons, they shouldn't)." So, in general, whatever the "natural" demand for gasoline is, lowering prices won't change that too much. num40 = 0
numrest = 0
n = 100000
for i in range(n):
    price = 46.11
    minprice = price
    changes = np.random.normal(mu, std, 100)
    for change in changes:
        price *= change + 1
        minprice = min(price, minprice)
    if (minprice < 34.00):
        num34 += 1
    elif (minprice < 40):
        num40 += 1
    else:
        numrest += 1 assert (num34 + num40 + numrest == n)
print num34, num40, numrest

Still thinking reduced demand will depress this market, but hard to get good signals on demand. Primary use of WTI is refined gasoline. Maybe upward pressure on demand, but then it's the math of reduced refining costs versus transportation costs versus the global alternative (going down). And on top of this, not all refineries are created equal (it is my understanding that refineries are, in some sense, optimized for particular grades). So unless and until the non-US refineries that are not optimized for WTI re-gear, the export ban (or lack thereof) effect is to be found in the basic (non-optimized) differential of pushing high grade crude through refineries optimized for low-grade crude. Most likely going to stay above $40 for now (Around $47 as of mid-September). Things to watch:
- What OPEC does (could be bullish, bearish, or neutral, depending)
- What the Fed does (raise may be mildly bearish, in the sense that it will slow growth slightly - although not immediately)
- How fast Iran's oil comes on line (my guess is that this will be a relatively slow process)
- The state of other large economies: China, Japan, EU (mixed basket here)
- Any sort of geopolitical disturbances (these typically happen during the summer though, and the usual players currently don't have a strong incentive to disrupt oil flow anyhow, with the possible exception of more refinery attacks in Saudi by extremists). These would likely cause oil to spike for a short period of time.
- Oversupply issues: we need to keep an eye on storage; if that maxes out, it could cause wild swings in price as producers scale back production that they are unable to store. My best guess is that it will vary between the low $40s and mid $50s for the next year or two, with possibly short-term movements in either direction. It's impossible to rule anything out right now though...

I did a very unscientific look back at previous "Fall's" (that is, the months between September and December) and it seemed like there were more times than not that the price of WTI had a bit of a dip. Granted, there were certainly things at the time that contributed to those dips, but... that... coupled with the Goldman Sachs' outlook, makes me think that oil will *certainly* dip below 40 at least once between now and the end of the calendar year. As my %'s indicated, I think it's far more likely that it dips, but stays above 34.

Too early to tell. There are numerous power players who will make a decisions that impact the price.
A few key factors should be the surplus of oil in the US as compared to storage capability, the results of the upcoming OPEC meeting (early Dec?), changes in US export regulations, and the effect a potential FED rate hike may have on the US business climate.

If I read the chart (http://www.cnbc.com/commodities/ - click on OIL) correctly, it fell below $40.00 as recently as last month. The WTI market is apparently only partially sensitive to global pricing (in that much of the production/refining capacity is locked within the U.S.), so domestic demand is an equally important consideration.

Due to relatively high oil production, slowing global demand, and declining oil futures, the trend over the next few months is definitely down.  One prediction had the price around $35 per barrel by the end of December.
